30ac9ee2b01e70bec4742c7adfef90b6.title: A great perspective on building your analytics function through different stages of growth.

a0ab64a3f38e.name: ThinkGrowth.org

collectionHeaderMetadata.description: Stories, insights, & ideas to help you and your business grow

header.description: Stories, insights, & ideas to help you and your business grow

a0ab64a3f38e.description: ThinkGrowth.org is a HubSpot publication. We bring you stories, insights, and ideas to help you and your business grow.

paragraphs.name: cf00
paragraphs.text: If you build software of any type, you need real event tracking. I don’t care what tool you use — Mixpanel and Heap are very similar and they’re both good. At this point I wouldn’t think too hard about what you’re tracking: just use Mixpanel’s autotrack or Heap’s default installation. If you realize you need a datapoint, you’ll find it’s already there. This approach does not scale well, but for now, it’ll do.

paragraphs.name: cf9b
paragraphs.text: I’m going to walk you through, stage by stage, how your startup should be doing analytics. At each stage, my recommendations are going to answer to the question “What’s the absolute least I can get away with?” We’re not here to build castles in the sky; we need answers as cheaply as possible.

paragraphs.name: c04a
paragraphs.text: Tristan, thanks for writing such a thoughtful article! I love that you cover “what to do” as well as “what NOT to do”. As an analyst / data nerd who’s seen several small businesses struggle with analytics, I know that some businesses underestimate the importance of having clean and relevant data, but several others “jump the gun” and are totally…

paragraphs.name: 53ec
paragraphs.text: Thanks for the insights Tristan! Very thorough best-practice on how to implemet analytics pipeline. Once all this is in place, let’s also not forget to ask the right questions and have a goal in mind before digging into the data. Too many times I’ve seen people spending hours creating analyses that didn’t add any value to their business. Think about how many of one’s dashboards and reports are not used…

paragraphs.text: That’s a totally fair point. Right now the way we see a lot of people answering questions like that at the founding stage is just connecting Mode Analytics directly to a production read replica. That obviously isn’t a solution that is particularly capable, but for many folks we find it falls into the “good enough” bucket at this stage.
